intro: Ligusticum mutellina var. elatius, commonly known as the greater lovage, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It is characterized by its aromatic, pinnately compound leaves and yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is known for its strong, spicy scent. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands or along waterways. The leaves and roots are used in traditional medicine and culinary applications.
